newsitem.title: GREECE: Greek shares end down on cash shortage, new law.
newsitem.headline: Greek shares end down on cash shortage, new law.

text.p: Greek equities fell another 1.13 percent in low turnover. Brokers said the market was hit by a combination of a cash shortage and the negative effect of a law governing investment services, effective November 1.

"The bourse came under selling pressure again today because of the lack of fresh cash injections and concern about the negative side effects of law 2396/96 governing the operation of investment firms in Greece," said a broker.

The chairman of Greece's Capital Markets Commission, Stavros Thomadakis, presented three regulations on Thursday concerning the implementation of law 2396/96 which was voted in parliament last April and goes into effect on November 1.
The law outlines the general framework governing the activities of firms offering investment services in Greece and harmonises Greek law with European Union legislation.
The broker said a number of brokerage houses are now being forced to reduce their equity holdings to pay for shares bought on behalf of their clients which they financed.

"I put the blame squarely on the government which should be aware of the current situation and the related problems," the broker said. "I am convinced the worse is not over yet unless something is done about extending the November 1 deadline."
"I expect a bourse recovery after the presentation of the 1997 budget," he said.
The market was waiting to see how National Economy and Finance Minister Yannos Papandoniou would shape the 1997 draft budget, due by the end of November.
The Athens general share index closed down 1.13 percent, or 10.55 points at 937.70 from Tuesday's 941.70 close after opening at 940.05 points.
Turnover was at 7.60 billion drachmas on volume of 4.47 million shares boosted by block trades in Parnassos, Alpha Credit Bank ACBr.AT and National Bank of Greece.
